text.value: This picture by Eugene Delacroix, painted about 150 years after Milton’s death, shows the poet dictating Paradise Lost to his daughters. Examine it and read an entry written about it for an exhibition programme.
In the passage, highlight the seven word allusion to the sonnet we are currently investigating.

The blind poet, his head tilted away from his girls towards some interior apparition, is both a patriarch and a visionary. Like Tiresias, his curse is the source of his gift.

What Milton cannot see is the frivolous and flowery foreground inhabited by his pretty kneeling daughter (they also serve who sit and write). She would probably prefer to be reading the novels at her feet and seems to belong, or to want to belong, to the indulgent 1660s – the era of Restoration – in which the scene is set.

What Milton can see is the Expulsion, depicted in the darkness behind. There is something radical about the image and characteristic of both Delacroix and Milton, for the looming winged figure, who must represent the angel Michael, is recast as a sinister, ungodly shadow.

So Delacroix’s Milton is still challenging convention, still seeing things differently. Indeed, the Civil War revolutionary is still dressed as a Puritan in stark black and white, an enemy to Popery and to the pomp and corruption of the restored Stuarts.
